## The Inspiration 

Health Canada and Environment and Climate Change Canada are
currently funding a joint study on the risk relationship
between exposure to particulate matter.

<br>

--
  - specifically particulate matter **components**
--

  - historical component data is limited
--

  - satellite remote sensing data **may** be usable (<a href="http://www.canue.ca">**will**</a> be usable in the near future)

---

class: inverse

## The Problem

- large numbers of missing observations in the **local** data
- coarse resolution for both temporal and spatial dimensions in the
  **remotely** sensed data
- mis-match in temporal coverage

<br>
--

**Can the two be used to improve one another?**

---

class: inverse middle

<small>Students at Virginia Tech studied which vehicles come to a
<font color="mediumpurple">complete stop</font> at an intersection with
four-way stop signs, selecting at random the cars to observe. 
The <font color="lightgreen">explanatory</font> variable used here is the arrival
position of vehicles approaching an intersection all traveling in the
same direction. They classified this arrival pattern into three groups:
whether the vehicle arrives alone (<code><small>single</small></code>),
is the <code><small>lead</small></code> in a group of
vehicles, or is a <code><small>follow</small></code>er in
a group of vehicles. Is there an association between <font
color="lightgreen">arrival pattern</font> and whether a <code><font
color="purple"><small>complete</small></font></code> stop or <code><font
color="purple"><small>not_complete</small></font></code> was made?</small>

<br>

<tiny>- From <a href="http://math.hope.edu/isi/"> 
"Introduction to Statistical Investigations"
</a> by Tintle et al.</tiny>
